title: VEGOILS-Palm rises for fifth straight session on rival oils strength
text:
VEGOILS-Palm rises for fifth straight session on rival oils strength

SINGAPORE, Oct 21 (Reuters) - Malaysian palm oil futures edged higher for the fifth consecutive session on Monday, tracking gains in rival oils, though a stronger ringgit limited gains.

The ringgit was last up 0.1% against the dollar, making the edible oil more expensive for holders of foreign currencies.

The benchmark palm oil contract for January delivery FCPOc3 on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives Exchange rose 0.3% to 2,294 ringgit ($548.48) per tonne at 0236 GMT.

Dalian's January palm oil contract DCPF0 was up 1% on Monday, while the January soyoil contract DBYF0 was 0.4% higher.

Elsewhere, U.S. soyoil futures on the Chicago Board of Trade BOc2 were up 0.3%.

Palm oil is affected by price movements in related oils as they compete for share in the global vegetable oils market.

Palm oil may test a resistance at 2,317 ringgit per tonne, a break above which could lead to a gain to 2,364 ringgit, said Reuters analyst Wang Tao. TECH/C

FUNDAMENTALS

* Chicago wheat futures lost ground on Monday as the market eased from its highest since late-June, although tightening world supplies and rising prices in top exporters limited losses. GRA/

* Oil prices eased on Monday amid concerns about the global economic outlook and the impact on oil demand, while Russia again missed its target to cut oil output last month. O/R

MARKET NEWS

* Asian stocks were steady in a cautious start to the week on Monday, while the British pound fell following a delay to a crucial vote on Britain's divorce from the European Union. MKTS/GLOB

* Sterling fell over half a percent against the dollar, slipping from five-month highs after the British parliament delayed a crucial vote on a Brexit withdrawal agreement. USD/
